segment.source: Disabling Secure Boot
segment.target: Disabling Secure Boot

segment.source: Disabling Secure Boot
segment.target: Disabling Secure Boot

segment.source: Disabling Secure Boot
segment.target: Disabling Secure Boot

segment.source: You may need to disable Secure Boot to run some PC graphics cards, hardware, or operating systems such as Linux or previous version of Windows.
segment.target: You may need to disable Secure Boot to run some PC graphics cards, hardware, or operating systems such as Linux or previous version of Windows.

segment.source: Secure Boot helps to make sure that your PC boots using only firmware that is trusted by the manufacturer.
segment.target: Secure Boot helps to make sure that your PC boots using only firmware that is trusted by the manufacturer.

segment.source: For most PCs, you can disable Secure Boot through the PC’s firmware (BIOS) menus.
segment.target: For most PCs, you can disable Secure Boot through the PC’s firmware (BIOS) menus.

segment.source: For logo-certified Windows RT 8.1 and Windows RT PCs, Secure Boot is required to be configured so that it cannot be disabled.
segment.target: For logo-certified Windows RT 8.1 and Windows RT PCs, Secure Boot is required to be configured so that it cannot be disabled.

segment.source: Warning
segment.target: Warning

segment.source: After disabling Secure Boot and installing other software and hardware, it may be difficult to re-activate Secure Boot without restoring your PC to the factory state.
segment.target: After disabling Secure Boot and installing other software and hardware, it may be difficult to re-activate Secure Boot without restoring your PC to the factory state.

segment.source: Be careful when changing BIOS settings.
segment.target: Be careful when changing BIOS settings.

segment.source: The BIOS menu is designed for advanced users, and it's possible to change a setting that could prevent your PC from starting correctly.
segment.target: The BIOS menu is designed for advanced users, and it's possible to change a setting that could prevent your PC from starting correctly.

segment.source: Be sure to follow the manufacturer's instructions exactly.
segment.target: Be sure to follow the manufacturer's instructions exactly.

segment.source: To disable Secure Boot:
segment.target: To disable Secure Boot:

segment.source: Before disabling Secure Boot, consider whether it is necessary.
segment.target: Before disabling Secure Boot, consider whether it is necessary.

segment.source: From time to time, your manufacturer may update the list of trusted hardware, drivers, and operating systems for your PC.
segment.target: From time to time, your manufacturer may update the list of trusted hardware, drivers, and operating systems for your PC.

segment.source: To check for updates, go to Windows Update, or check your manufacturer's website.
segment.target: To check for updates, go to Windows Update, or check your manufacturer's website.

segment.source: Open the PC BIOS menu.
segment.target: Open the PC BIOS menu.

segment.source: You can often access this menu by pressing a key during the bootup sequence, such as F1, F2, F12, or Esc.
segment.target: You can often access this menu by pressing a key during the bootup sequence, such as F1, F2, F12, or Esc.

segment.source: Or, from Windows, hold the Shift key while selecting Restart.
segment.target: Or, from Windows, hold the Shift key while selecting Restart.

segment.source: Go to Troubleshoot Advanced Options: UEFI Firmware Settings.
segment.target: Go to Troubleshoot Advanced Options: UEFI Firmware Settings.

segment.source: Find the Secure Boot setting, and if possible, set it to Disabled.
segment.target: Find the Secure Boot setting, and if possible, set it to Disabled.

segment.source: This option is usually in either the Security tab, the Boot tab, or the Authentication tab.
segment.target: This option is usually in either the Security tab, the Boot tab, or the Authentication tab.

segment.source: Save changes and exit.
segment.target: Save changes and exit.

segment.source: The PC reboots.
segment.target: The PC reboots.

segment.source: Install the graphics card, hardware, or operating system that’s not compatible with Secure Boot.
segment.target: Install the graphics card, hardware, or operating system that’s not compatible with Secure Boot.

segment.source: In some cases, you may need to change other settings in the firmware, such as enabling a Compatibility Support Module (CSM) to support legacy BIOS operating systems.
segment.target: In some cases, you may need to change other settings in the firmware, such as enabling a Compatibility Support Module (CSM) to support legacy BIOS operating systems.

segment.source: To use a CSM, you may also need to reformat the hard drive using the Master Boot Record (MBR) format, and then reinstall Windows.
segment.target: To use a CSM, you may also need to reformat the hard drive using the Master Boot Record (MBR) format, and then reinstall Windows.

segment.source: For more info, see Windows Setup: Installing using the MBR or GPT partition style.
segment.target: For more info, see Windows Setup: Installing using the MBR or GPT partition style.

segment.source: If you’re using Windows 8.1, you may see a watermark on the desktop alerting you that Secure Boot is not configured correctly.
segment.target: If you’re using Windows 8.1, you may see a watermark on the desktop alerting you that Secure Boot is not configured correctly.

segment.source: Get this update to remove the Secure Boot desktop watermark.
segment.target: Get this update to remove the Secure Boot desktop watermark.

segment.source: To re-enable Secure Boot:
segment.target: To re-enable Secure Boot:

segment.source: Uninstall any graphics cards, hardware, or operating systems that aren’t compatible with Secure Boot.
segment.target: Uninstall any graphics cards, hardware, or operating systems that aren’t compatible with Secure Boot.

segment.source: Open the PC BIOS menu.
segment.target: Open the PC BIOS menu.

segment.source: You can often access this menu by pressing a key during the bootup sequence, such as F1, F2, F12, or Esc.
segment.target: You can often access this menu by pressing a key during the bootup sequence, such as F1, F2, F12, or Esc.

segment.source: Or, from Windows: go to Settings charm Change PC settings Update and Recovery Recovery Advanced Startup: Restart now.
segment.target: Or, from Windows: go to Settings charm Change PC settings Update and Recovery Recovery Advanced Startup: Restart now.

segment.source: When the PC reboots, go to Troubleshoot Advanced Options: UEFI Firmware Settings.
segment.target: When the PC reboots, go to Troubleshoot Advanced Options: UEFI Firmware Settings.

segment.source: Find the Secure Boot setting, and if possible, set it to Enabled.
segment.target: Find the Secure Boot setting, and if possible, set it to Enabled.

segment.source: This option is usually in either the Security tab, the Boot tab, or the Authentication tab.
segment.target: This option is usually in either the Security tab, the Boot tab, or the Authentication tab.

segment.source: On some PCs, select Custom, and then load the Secure Boot keys that are built into the PC.
segment.target: On some PCs, select Custom, and then load the Secure Boot keys that are built into the PC.

segment.source: If the PC does not allow you to enable Secure Boot, try resetting the BIOS back to the factory settings.
segment.target: If the PC does not allow you to enable Secure Boot, try resetting the BIOS back to the factory settings.

segment.source: Save changes and exit.
segment.target: Save changes and exit.

segment.source: The PC reboots.
segment.target: The PC reboots.

segment.source: If the PC is not able to boot after enabling Secure Boot, go back into the BIOS menus, disable Secure Boot, and try to boot the PC again.
segment.target: If the PC is not able to boot after enabling Secure Boot, go back into the BIOS menus, disable Secure Boot, and try to boot the PC again.

segment.source: In some cases, you may need to refresh or reset your PC to its original state before you can turn on Secure Boot.
segment.target: In some cases, you may need to refresh or reset your PC to its original state before you can turn on Secure Boot.

segment.source: For more info, see How to restore, refresh, or reset your PC.
segment.target: For more info, see How to restore, refresh, or reset your PC.

segment.source: If the above steps don’t work, and you still want to use the Secure Boot feature, contact your manufacturer for help.
segment.target: If the above steps don’t work, and you still want to use the Secure Boot feature, contact your manufacturer for help.

segment.source: For additional troubleshooting steps for PC manufacturers: see Secure Boot isn't configured correctly: Determine if the PC is in a manufacturing mode (info for manufacturers).
segment.target: For additional troubleshooting steps for PC manufacturers: see Secure Boot isn't configured correctly: Determine if the PC is in a manufacturing mode (info for manufacturers).

segment.source: Related topics
segment.target: Related topics

segment.target: Secure Boot Overview

segment.target: Secure Boot isn't configured correctly: troubleshooting
